newsitem.title: USA: Bid to reopen famous U.S. murder case moves ahead.
newsitem.headline: Bid to reopen famous U.S. murder case moves ahead.

text.p: A local judge on Thursday said he would hear motions next month in a bid to reopen the 43-year-old murder case that inspired "The Fugitive" TV series and movie.
Judge Ronald Suster of Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court asked the parties involved to return to court on June 2 after which he could throw the case out or set a trial date.

The case involves Sam Sheppard, a Cleveland osteopath convicted of second-degree murder in the 1954 killing of his pregnant wife Marilyn. He was acquitted in a new trial in 1966 and died at the age of 46 in 1970.

His son, Sam Reese Sheppard, is seeking a civil trial and a finding that his father was wrongfully convicted at the first trial -- a move that would clear his father's name completely and open the way for him to collect damages from the state.
His lawyer contends that evidence was withheld that would have cleared his father earlier and that blood at the crime scene linked the murder to a former handyman for the family.
Assistant County Prosecutor Carmen Marino said on Thursday no evidence was withheld and his office has nothing left to turn over in the case.

Hollywood's version of the "Fugitive" holds little resemblance to the Sheppard case since Sheppard was arrested a month after the murder and convicted six months later. He maintained his innocence throughout, contending a home invader killed his wife.
In the movie and TV series, the "fugitive" escapes from custody and goes underground to clear his name.
